pros: Wonderful staff and patients. Makes the work meaningful.
cons: Hard work but worth every day.

pros: The former staff were right, great beginner’s experience. Lasted on the island for a year, finally got my own office after months of sharing one. Free food, but it’s low quality. They give you this sarcastic illusion that you are valued and this is a family when it’s a lie. They offered a bonus and holiday pay and I never got it. Barely a thank you staying over completing work. I guess some pros are when you have off and accumulate pto and the handful of pts that aren’t dicks that make you smile.
cons: Upper mgmt has this illusion they are the biggest kid in the play ground and will talk about those who quit, twist the stories and cry about it forever. Like how dare those ppl to have a back bone and want better? They treat employees horribly and act like this is only job that is out there. They literally threaten ppl and use intimidation, it’s disgusting. Creates hostility. Don’t miss the email blasts like it’s the 1960s and the bullying. There was lack of team anything, it was toxic. We had the same meetings about the same things repeatedly and were given additional work load. 80 percent of this job was documentation and towards the end group therapy was a reasonable size, not 25 ppl. Sometimes I had three group therapies, when someone calls off, I have two group therapies in a day plus individual sessions. I had a caseload of eight ppl to ten ppl. I barely had a break. They don’t care if therapist get beaten up by pts, they want all problems brushed under the rug. I trained myself. Everything pretty much is a con.

review_title: Solid Place to Grow as a Professional
pros: Career ladder opportunities to advance
cons: Tough population and staffing issues

pros: The clients were awesome and made it bearable
cons: I was more knowledgeable than the therapist

pros: Very team oriented, fast paced enviroment. Focus on the patient
cons: Unfortunately it is the nature of the business, but holidays and weekends are often part of the schedule.

pros: Awesome coworkers, new management has helped, able to be creative with groups
cons: Low staffing and low pay

pros: Occasional free lunches. free parking,
cons:
FACTS:
Benefits: 401K, STD and LTD after 1 year, 401K 3% match, vested after 3 years. Health is ICHRA, basically subcontractor picks 7-8 choices from the BIG names in your area in the marketplace. Then, based on age and family component, you get a $$$ amount to pick from the choices. Bottom line, health benefits can run from a tank of gas to that new car payment in cost. Overall, health benefits are average at best. Dental and Vision, below average but cheap. All start first of month after start date.

PTO: they love to claim up to 29 days*** (note asterisk). 29 days is possible provided you work greater than 60 hours a week AND get approved for the OT. ACTUAL PTO is closer to 18 days. NOTE: NO PAID HOLIDAYS (you pay yourself via your PTO), NO SICK DAYS. Therefore, after the 5 or 6 holidays, your actual usable PTO is 12 to 13 days.

Staffing: like everywhere else, short-staffed. For RN's expect to be mandated 2-3 times a quarter. Pseudo self scheduling, pick the w/e you cannot work, and they pick everything else.

Breaks: take up smoking, as that is the only way you get breaks. Lunch and breaks are rare, although they deduct the lunch from your paycheck.

Compensation: slightly below market averages for licensed/certified staff, for unlicensed/certified staff, Walmart pays $5 an hour more! Raises: LESS than 1%

Management: New(er) management, talented, but absent most of the time. Although they micromanage well via email, and while they are absent, they surprisingly know about things that happen almost immediately (funny how that is). New management inherited a mess, the current thought process is to streamline, which means more job duties for the staff.

Work environment: Some VERY talented people, and then some... well, not everyone can be talented. 

Culture: Will spend $$$ on silly things like paintings and rocking chairs, but all the computers are over 10 years old and other than the lobby the decors is not well maintained and very dated. Money is not invested into staff and clearly not the premises.

Advancement: zero, and to be honest you probably would not want the responsibility anyway.

Staff Development: They can't staff to start with. The few things they expect you to do on your own time, getting paid for it is a challenge.

Overall, a revolving door, lately though they do not replace, just add more job duties to the staff. For RN's, many non-nursing job functions.

pros: Some of the employees were willing to help.
cons:
There is no communication between management and employees. Everyone is short staffed and stressed out at all times and you are pulled in all different directions.

You will not get a lunch break but it is deducted automatically.

This is a smoking facility.

Staff has no time to train. While training, they are already experiencing burnout so you're getting minimal training by stressed employees.

job_title: Chemical Dependency Counselor in Youngstown, OH
pros: Flexibility, PTO, almost 14 an hour to start, training and experience in a good field, nice opportunity to learn and gain knowledge about drug and alcohol addictions as well as emotional issues.
cons: I don’t think there are any cons. Maybe the fact that all your additional training is paid by you and not the company, I feel if your there each day the company should show they want to keep you by paying the education needed to continue to hold you licensing as a CDCA.

pros: Good paid time off, ability to have some flexibility in schedule, not micromanaged, experience working with a diverse population, gain de-escalation and conflict resolution experience
cons: high rate of employee turnover and burnout, high rate of patient recidivism, most clinical managers lack motivation and offer little support to their staff, very little concern on quality of treatment delivered to patients, front line staff are often overworked and underqualified for their jobs which helps to create the high patient recidivism, lack of consequences and consistency for patients or staff, financial problems in company, upper level management is far removed from direct care staff

review_title: benefits=good, middle management=decent, upper management=needs much improvement
pros: Benefits package is good, especially Paid Time Off (PTO). Most front line supervisors care about the clients and the employees.
cons: The upper management does not keep their finger on the pulse of its employees. The overall employee moral is low and it is not being practicality addressed.

pros: Easily get OT. Working with different types of people
cons: Inconsistent among management. Favoritism. Correctional mindset when all they really are is a holding place for state parolees. Pretty much they treat all their clients (including the ones genuinely there for rehab) as prisoners of the state. Only good CCC is Dave. Dave will look out for his staff, he is consistent, and honest.

review_title: Love the job, pay is terrible, benefits are fantastic. Awesome management, HR is terrible and in a different town.
